Description: Reconstructed rim, body, handle, and splayed foot (mended from six fragments) of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: reserved band at top of lip, glazed black below; exterior: black band at top of lip; lip and handle zone reserved with band between, glazed below including outside of foot; reserved underside.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer identifies the sherd as belonging to a Type 9A South Ionian cup with everted rim. The type closely follows the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18), Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-6), and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-8). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. 'A 1277' is written on a sticker glued to the interior surface of the rim.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (A1277)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 50, no. 126, p. 98, NAU 45, pl. 10 e-g)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.319) (Phase 3)
